content.description: Red Sky shares the start of Moon Juice, and is an enterprising mixed pitch. Climb as you would for that route, but continue straight up working your way towards the sweeping dihedral at the top.  Several thought intensive cruxes, and a bit of decent fingers laybacking at the top.
content.protection: Bolts, finger sized cams, chain anchors.

climbs.name: Pickpocket
climbs.fa: Jeremy Nelson, Albert Newman, Rob Tomczak

content.description:
3 bolts protect the thin and loose section of the rock, small gear to bolts to big gear to the top. Fun route, good protection.  

  The last route to be established in Sedona of 2003.

This is a fine little warm up pitch that will get better with traffic. Start up the slabby left facing dihedral, and clip the first bolt before the ledge. Move up the dihedral above you, then move right to the arete. Piece the pockets and crimps together, and stay on those toes. Pass a thoughtful mantle, then a few hard cranks and the chains.
content.location: Middle left side of the crag.

content.description: Moon Juice is a classic bit of sport climbing sitting high above the church, which for the grade, stands out as one of the better sport pitches in Sedona. If it's cold out, this south facing route is guaranteed to warm you up one way or another.Look for the overhanging arete with huecos and large rails! Shares start with Red Sky. Start up vertical face and figure out the tricky low crux, then pick your way past a heavily pocketed band of stone. Take a quick break at the base of the overhanging arête, a few deep breaths I suppose, then bust out the little entrance boulder problem... Climb up past amazing features on the arete and holds out right to the last crux at the final bulge. Finish up crimpy slab to the original anchors of Red Sky.
content.location: To the left of the mini tower.

content.description: East side of MiniMe tower. Climb up easy face to single bolt. Move up (crux) into awesome hands under small roof. Up crack to tower top. Rappel 50 feet on one good bolt
content.location: Contour base of Upper Beach to far right (East) side. Go around to the east side of obvious Mini Me tower and look for bolt down low.  See Bloom/Wolfe guide Sedona Rocks!

content.description: Go With The Flow is a superb trad route which is also laborious, tricky, powerful, and pumpy! Work your way up the right facing dihedral to a stem/face/mantel crux with a bolt. After that work up to the small roof, then out and left. Watch your rope run here, cause there is still some hard climbing above. Fisty at the top! It is a burly onsight!
content.protection: Double set, runners, wires, chain anchor.
content.location: Scurry through the notch between the little tower and the main wall. Walk down a bit and look for this obvious line.

content.description: Super fun mixed route left of Kenny Ate the Cheeseburger. Obvious left-facing short corner to bolted face.
content.protection: singles 0 TCU - #3 Camalot.  4 draws for bolted face.
content.location: One of the leftmost routes at the Upper Beach. Look for obvious left-facing corner on a short tower.

content.description: Hike up to left facing corner. Layback pods past a bolt to a short corner with gear. Cruise patinesque up the upper corner until the final bolt. Slab move to anchor.     BurchamCo originally put one bolt in the anchor but were called away to meet the Dali Lama. Listed as 'project' in "Sedona Rocks".
content.location: Starts 20' right of Fame and Money. Look for a system of left facing corners.

content.description: An intimidating line when you first put your eyes on it. The Dangling Monkey is a proper roof crack that will test almost anyone who tries it. Start off with a 75' first pitch of 5.10+ crack climbing that gets you to a bolted belay below the looming roof. When ready, launch out into the steep roof crack and get your swing on! Has been done in one long pitch.
content.location: Two routes left of the little tower.

content.description: This short trad line like its namesake is fun, but you need to keep the sand out of your jean shorts.EZ Left facing corner leads to thin crack. Once into the flare, enjoy nice jams but get ready to spike it over the top!!!!
content.protection: 2x tips to thin hands. Bolted anchor on top.
content.location: Start 20' left of Nurse Ratchet. Look for a varnished flare 30' up.

content.description: Corona is the long, just under vertical face with rippled holds and pockets.  A great warm up, and it gets better and better the more times you do it.
content.location: Presently has it's own wall...  Left/middle of the area.

content.description: This short, slightly overhanging route provides an excellent pump, and thought provoking cruxes! A good warmup for the harder pitches.
content.location: To the climber’s right of the Corona wall.

content.description:
The Upper Beach is a winter time getaway which faces pretty much due south.  Located on the high tannish band of stone above the Chapel of the Cross, this crag has a handful of clever routes both trad and sport. The rock is very good for Sedona and sports ripple crimps, bomber huecos, deep pockets, and crisp cracks at angles that will surprise you.   

  Needless to say the views are expansive, though the Chapel and the adjacent neighborhood take off a few points for sure.  All in all a fun place to soak up the sun, and have some fun.
